''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive,and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive,and decides instead to fly off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''CURIOUS GEORGE,'' a book about a lovable little monkey by Margaret E. Rey, has been adapted into a musical by Thomas Toce and Theaterworks/USA, tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Lovinger Theater, Speech and Theater Building, Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, Bronx. Tickets: $5. Tickets: advance purchase, (718) 960-8833; day of performance, (718) 960-8025.

''I NEVER SAW ANOTHER BUTTERFLY,'' a new adaptation by Geraldine Teagarden and Sharon Talbot of the play by Celeste Raspanti about children in the Theresienstadt concentration camp who left behind poetry, artwork and music. Mazer Theater, 197 East Broadway, Lower East Side. Tonight at 7; tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday at 3 p.m.Tickets: $12. Reservations: (212) 532-8887.

''JACK AND THE BEANSTALK.'' The Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater presents an updated version of the classic fairy tale with music, puppetry and comedy. Tuesdays through Fridays at 10:30 a.m. and noon; Saturdays at 1 p.m. Through June. Central Park, West Drive at 79th Street, enter at 81st Street and Central Park West or 79th Street and Fifth Avenue. Admission: $5; $4 for children. Reservations required: (212) 988-9093.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed in Spanish and English simultaneously), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the familiar story but with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. through June 25. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''Y2KIDS: STORIES AND SONGS FOR THE NEW MILLENNIUM,'' a show that is part musical revue, part drama and part poetry recitation, is performed by the members of New York Youth Theater's junior company, who are 5 to 11 years old. The show includes music by Carole King, Harry Chapin and Irving Berlin. Fridays at 7 p.m.; Saturdays at 1 and 5 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. at the Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street, seventh floor, through June 11. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 888-0696.
Events

BACK PORCH CRAFT SERIES, Saturdays through June at 1 p.m. at the Dyckman Farmhouse, Broadway and 204th Street, Manhattan, will focus on traditional 18th-century crafts. Tomorrow children and adults can relax on the back porch of the Dutch colonial farmouse and learn how to embroider. Free. Information: (212) 304-9422.

CENTRAL PARK CONSERVANCY will hold two workshops tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m.: map-making with youngsters recording their memories of places in Central Park that have personal meaning, at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370; creating an enclosed terrarium, at the Henry Luce Nature Observatory at Belvedere Castle, midpark at 79th Street, (212) 772-0210.

CHILDREN'S SPRINGTIME GARDEN PARTY, Sunday from 1 to 3 p.m. at Mount Vernon Hotel Museum, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. The structure, built in 1799, will be the perfect setting for Mother Goose nursery rhymes, 19th-century children's games and sing-alongs. Tickets: $6; $4 for children.

CIRCUS SUNDAYS IN JUNE. Comic magicians, Brazilian stilt-dancers, hand balancers and jugglers and a virtuoso on cowbells will perform at Red Hook's Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge, (the historic 1914 Lehigh Valley Railroad Barge No. 79) docked at the foot of Conover Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, rain or shine, at 2 and 4 p.m. A Con Edison shuttle bus will offer a free ride to the barge from Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens and Red Hook. Ringside reservations: $5; free showtime. Information: (718) 624-4719.

CIVIL WAR ENCAMPMENT. Civil War re-enactors will take visitors inside a camp site and perform an infantry drill, tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Queens County Farm Museum, 73-50 Little Neck Parkway, Floral Park. A battle re-enactment will take place at 1 p.m. Admission: $2. Information: (718) 347-3276.

CREATIVE ARTS STUDIO SPRING DANCE CONCERT, tomorrow at 7 p.m. at Long Island University Triangle Theater, University Plaza, Brooklyn. Students of the Creative Arts Studio Performance Workshop, who are 9 and older, will perform. Tickets: $10 for adults; $5 for children. Reservations: (718) 797-5600.

FLAMENCO DANCE AND MUSIC. Andrea del Conte Danza Espana will perform flamenco dances, tomorrow at 4 p.m. at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, in the second floor Islamic Galleries. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

''FURNISHED BY NATURE.'' Visitors to Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. can create miniature furniture and decorations inspired by the exhibition ''Welcome,'' works by 11 artists exploring ideas of home (through Aug. 20). Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free from 9 a.m. to noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.

FAMILY CONCERT AT THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY. Songs by Tom Chapin, including ''Family Tree,'' ''Moonboat,'' ''Mother Earth'' and ''Billy the Squid,'' will be featured in a family concert tomorrow at 11 a.m. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 621-0618. Free tickets will be given out in the Central Children's Room one hour before the concert on a first-come, first-served basis.

''FORBIDDEN PLANET,'' a 1956 futuristic version of ''The Tempest'' by Shakespeare, will be screened as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center's ''Movies for Kids'' series tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m. For children 6 and older. Tickets: $3. Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5600.

JUNE BALLOON FAMILY ARTS FESTIVAL, an annual festival at the Brooklyn Children's Museum and adjacent Brower Park, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, will take place Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. There will be a Latino theme, with bands and dancers, food, and arts and crafts workshops. Outdoor activities are free. Museum hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 6:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; closed Tuesdays. Reduced admission of $1 for the museum's exhibtions.

KEEP IT COOL. Cold-blooded (but friendly) creatures from the Staten Island Zoo will be guests Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Free with museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Information: (718) 273-2060.

''OVER THE RAINBOW,'' two programs by the Brooklyn Youth Chorus, tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m. (the 2 p.m. performance will be a children's matinee), at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church, Sixth Avenue between Park Place and Sterling Place, three blocks off Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Tickets: $5 to $25. Information: (718) 243-9447.

''REMEMBER PLAYING MARBLES?'' On view weekends through July 2, the Prospect Park Alliance and Urban Glass present ''Marble Millennium: Historic and Contemporary Marble Exhibit,'' at the Grand Army Plaza Arch Gallery in Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Marble enthusiasts will conduct workshops on traditional marble games under the arch on Saturdays and Sundays from noon to 4 p.m. Visitors are asked to donate $1 or more for park maintenance at the park's major entrances. The No. 2 and No. 3 trains and the B41 and B69 buses go to Grand Army Plaza. Information: (718) 965-8954.

STONE-CARVING DEMONSTRATIONS AND SOAP SCULPTURE WORKSHOP. In conjunction with ''The Art of William Edmondson,'' an exhibition of limestone carving by the artist, the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, will present stone-carving demonstrations tomorrow from 1 to 5 p.m. (also June 24, July 29 and Aug. 26) and a soap-carving workshop for children ages 5 to 12 on Sunday from 2 to 4 p.m. (also July 9 and July 23). Free; $1 materials fee for the workshop. Information and reservations: (212) 595-9533.
Exhibitions

''A YEAR WITH CHILDREN.'' The annual exhibition organized by Learning Through Art/The Guggenheim Museum Children's Program, with artwork and writing by elementary school students from about 60 classrooms in New York City and New Jersey, as well as children in Mexico City, Italy and Spain, will be on view through June 18 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; closed Thursdays. Admission: $12; $7 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 accompanied by an adult. It's pay what you wish Fridays 6 to 8 P.M. Information: (212) 423-3500.
